Legal_Issue: Whether Mr. Ivor Hughes is guilty of contempt of court for disclosing confidential material contrary to a protective order
Governing_Law: Protective order issued by the court
Evidence_Assessment: Disclosure of material believed to be non-confidential
Decision_Outcome: Guilty of contempt, but granted discharge with reduced costs
Credibility_Factor: Sincere apology and good faith belief
Legal_Rule: An officer of the court must respect and enforce court orders; technical breach in good faith may still constitute contempt
Procedural_Issue: Initial acquittal overturned on appeal due to legal error
Grounds_for_Claim: Disclosure of material in violation of protective order
Judicial_Review_Outcome: Appeal allowed, guilt confirmed, penalty adjusted
Review_Standard: Correctness regarding interpretation of protective order
Procedural_Fairness_Assessment: Fair process followed; opportunity to respond given
Key_Evidence_Considered: Nature of disclosed material, intent, legal advice, trial judge's prior interpretation
Legal_Framework: Contempt of court principles, duties of officers of the court
Applicant_Challenge: Error of law in initial acquittal
Court_Result: Contempt found, discharge granted, costs reduced to $15,000
Legal_Rule_Source: Common law, court rules and precedents on contempt
Defendant_Response: Belief that material was not confidential under the order
Evidence_Type: Documentary disclosure, legal submissions, judicial findings
Remedy_Requested: Enforcement of protective order, sanctions for breach
Remedy_Sought: Penalty for breach of court order
Legal_Provision: Court's inherent jurisdiction to punish contempt
Authority: Court as guardian of its own orders
Claimant_Status: Party seeking enforcement of protective order
Grounds_for_Inadmissibility_or_Allegatio: Violation of protective order through disclosure
Governing_Rule: Protective order and rules governing conduct of legal officers
